thread.title: Trump Pushes For A Faster Pace On Repealing Obamacare
thread.title_full: Trump Pushes For A Faster Pace On Repealing Obamacare

author: Jack Davis
title: Trump Pushes For A Faster Pace On Repealing Obamacare
text:
Trump Pushes For A Faster Pace On Repealing Obamacare "... get to business ..." Share on Facebook Share Tweet Email Email Print Advertisement - story continues below 
President-elect Donald Trump wants Obamacare on the scrap heap, and he’s turning up the heat to get the job done fast. 
“We have to get to business ,” Trump told Congress on Tuesday. “Obamacare has been a catastrophic event.” 
House Speaker Paul Ryan, R-Wis., has implied that the pace of repeal might be somewhat deliberate, but noted that “it is our goal to bring it all together concurrently.” Advertisement - story continues below ‘The View’ Co-Host: Celebs Should Keep Their Political Beliefs To Themselves 
Trump, however, spoke Tuesday about a repeal vote “probably some time next week” and a replacement “very quickly or simultaneously, very shortly thereafter.” Trump has noted in the past that the timing of implementing repeal would allow for continued coverage until a replacement plan is fully effective. 
Although repealing Obamacare has been a Republican mantra for several years, now that responsibility for the nation’s health care system rests with the party that controls the House and Senate and will soon control the White House, some in Congress have urged caution. 
“In an ideal situation, we would repeal and replace Obamacare simultaneously, but we need to make sure that we have at least a detailed framework that tells the American people what direction we’re headed,” said Sen. Susan Collins, R-Maine, who supports a March 3 deadline for repeal legislation to be completed. Advertisement - story continues below 
Trump, however, wants full speed ahead. 
“I feel that repeal and replace have to be together, for, very simply, I think that the Democrats should want to fix Obamacare,” he said. “They cannot live with it, and they have to go together.” 
Trump said he will keep trying until repeal is passed. 
“It may not get approved the first time, and it may not get approved the second time, but the Democrats who will try not to approve it” will face a risk, he said. Advertisement - story continues below
